1) Automated suggestions to follow-up with contacts based on context of communication (including content of emails).  
2) Contact management features such as contact-deduplication and extraction of contact information from email signatures. 
3) Algorithms to automatic construction of a sales process; such as automatically determining when to add a contact to a sales account.  
4) Automatically determining the closest connection of the sales team to a sales lead. 
5) Machine learning models for parsing emails, extracting content from emails and webpages, and measuring strength of relationships.

January 2011  –  May 2012  (1 year 5 months) - Measuring Impacts on User Engagement: I led this project in which we developed a system to measure the impact of user-experience changes on long-term engagement of users. Our emphasis was on deriving causal links relying mainly on pre-existing (observational) log-data; i.e. without having to run randomized experiments. The first study quantitatively characterized the impact of spam-exposure on long-term user-engagement. 
- Modeling Social Systems: I extensively researched social system dynamics: modeling the reasons why users link to each other, the propagation of trends, and the production of content on social systems. 
- Mining Hidden User Intent: I worked extensively on modeling the observed behavior of users to mine their hidden intents. This work resulted in systems to help determine the user intent in ambiguous web search queries (mining facets), in computational advertising systems (commercial intent in queries), and social systems (the reason behind linking). 
- Web Search Systems: I worked on many layers of the web-search technology stack: from devising low-level indexing and early-termination optimizations all the way up to improving the display of search results (summarizing tweets, shortening page-titles, generating quicklinks and query-suggestions, etc.) 
- Abuse Detection and Prevention: In this long-running project I developed systems for mail- spam detection, detection and prevention of phishing, design and stress-tests of CAPTCHAs, and data mining of logs to detect abusive behavior. Summary Yehuda Koren is a staff research scientist at Google. Prior to this, he was a senior research scientist at Yahoo! Research and a principal staff member of AT&T Labs-Research. He received the PhD degree in computer science from The Weizmann Institute. His main research interests are recommender systems, data mining, machine learning, and information visualization. He led the team that won the two progress awards in the Netflix Prize competition, and was part of the team which won the Netflix Grand Prize. Dr. Koren has more than 50 research publications and several patents to his credit. He was awarded the best paper awards at INFOVIS 2005, KDD 2009, and RecSys 2011.He is serving as a senior program committee member at conferences like KDD, ICDM, RecSys, WSDM, and CIKM, and on the editorial board of IEEE TKDE and ACM TIST.
